[/INST]  In the case of Charles Rhines, a South Dakota court convicted him of murder and he filed a habeas corpus petition in federal court, alleging various constitutional violations in his trial and conviction. The federal district court ruled that Rhines had failed to exhaust all of his claims in state court, and therefore, his habeas petition was dismissed. However, the court stayed the petition to allow Rhines to pursue his claims in state court. This stay prevented the one-year statute of limitations in the federal Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act from barring Rhines from appealing to a federal court once he had exhausted his state remedies.

The state penitentiary warden appealed the decision, and the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court's ruling. The Eighth Circuit held that the Supreme Court's decision in Rose v. Lundy (1982) required the dismissal of a habeas petition that included unexhausted claims. The Supreme Court later affirmed the Eighth Circuit's decision in the case of Rhines v. Weinsberg (2004).

The issue in the case was whether a federal district court has the authority to stay a habeas petition to allow the petitioner to exhaust their claims in state court. The Supreme Court held that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act requires a federal district court to dismiss a habeas petition that includes unexhausted claims, unless the petitioner can demonstrate that it is "clearly established" that the state court would not have addressed the unexhausted claims. The Court held that the petitioner must demonstrate that it is "more likely than not" that the state court would have addressed the unexhausted claims.

In summary, the Supreme Court's decision in Rose v. Lundy (1982) and subsequent cases have established that a federal district court has the authority to stay a habeas petition to allow the petitioner to exhaust their claims in state court, but the petitioner must demonstrate that it is "more likely than not" that the state court would have addressed the unexhausted claims.'}]

column2: Shortly after taking office, President Bush created by executive order the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, a program aimed at allowing religious charitable organizations to compete alongside non-religious ones for federal funding. Another executive order instructed various executive departments to hold conferences promoting the Faith-Based Initiative. The Freedom from Religion Foundation sued, alleging that the conferences favored religious organizations over non-religious ones and thereby violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. The government argued that there was no "Case or Controversy" as required by Article III of the Constitution. According to the government, the Foundation had no standing to sue, because the Foundation had not been harmed in any way by the conferences. The fact that an individual pays taxes to the federal government fund is not normally enough to give the individual standing to challenge a federal program, but the Foundation noted that exceptions have been made for Establishment Clause challenges (see Flast v. Cohen and Bowen v. Kendrick ). The District Court ruled that the Foundation lacked standing to sue. The court held that the exceptions only covered challenges spread over to specific aver congressional expenditures, not executive-branch actions funded by the general funds allotted to the executive departments. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, ruling that any taxpayer has standing to bring an Establishment Clause challenge against an universal executive-branch program, whether funded by a specific congressional grant or by a discretionary collection use of a general appropriation.
column3: The winner of this case is Jay F. Hein, Director, White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, et al..

[/INST]  In the case of Bush v. Freedom from Religion Foundation, the plaintiff, the Freedom from Religion Foundation, sued the government after President Bush created the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives through an executive order. The Foundation argued that the program violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment by allowing religious charitable organizations to compete for federal funding alongside non-religious organizations. The government argued that the Foundation lacked standing to sue because it had not been directly harmed by the program.

The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which ultimately ruled in favor of the Foundation. The Court held that any taxpayer has standing to bring an Establishment Clause challenge against an executive-branch program, regardless of whether it is funded by a specific congressional grant or by a discretionary collection of a general appropriation. This decision was based on the principle that taxpayers have a direct and concrete interest in the expenditure of public funds and the enforcement of the Establishment Clause.

The government had argued that the exceptions to the standing requirements established in Flast v. Cohen and Bowen v. Kendrick only applied to challenges to specific congressional expenditures, and not to executive-branch actions funded by the general funds allotted to the executive departments. However, the Supreme Court held that these exceptions apply more broadly to any challenge to an executive-branch program, regardless of how it is funded.

In conclusion, the Supreme Court's decision in Bush v. Freedom from Religion Foundation established that any taxpayer has standing to bring an Establishment Clause challenge against an executive-branch program, regardless of how it is funded. This decision has significant implications for the ability of individuals to challenge government actions that they believe violate the First Amendment's Establishment Clause.'}]

The remedies available under the CWA, federal oversight and withholding of funds from noncompliant states, are very similar to the remedies addressed by the Court in Blessing ??so similar that we think the Court?™s decision practically compels our conclusion. Suter, 503 U.S. at 360, 112 S.Ct. 1360 [/INST]  The Eleventh Amendment immunity is a jurisdictional bar that prevents federal courts from exercising jurisdiction over suits against a state or its officials. The Supreme Court has held that Congress must explicitly abrogate a state's Eleventh Amendment immunity in order for a private party to sue a state officer in federal court.

In Blessing v. Freestone, the Supreme Court held that Congress did not explicitly abrogate the Eleventh Amendment immunity when it enacted the Civil Rights Act of 1991, which provided for damages for intentional discrimination by state officials. The Court held that the Act did not provide for damages against state officials, and therefore did not abrogate the Eleventh Amendment immunity.

In the present case, the Eleventh Amendment immunity is not at issue, as the Directors are suing the state officials in their official capacity. The Supreme Court has held that suits against state officials in their official capacity are not barred by the Eleventh Amendment, as they are not suits against the state itself. See Hafer v. Melo, 402 U.S. 1 (1971).

The Court in Blessing held that the remedies available under the Civil Rights Act of 1991, including the withholding of federal funds, are not sufficient to demonstrate Congress's intent to foreclose the availability of a Â§ 1983 action. The Court held that these remedies are similar to the remedies available under the CWA, and therefore, the Directors are not entitled to Eleventh Amendment immunity on this ground.

In conclusion, the Eleventh Amendment immunity is not a bar to the Directors' suit against the state officials in their official capacity. The Supreme Court has held that suits against state officials in their official capacity are not barred by the Eleventh Amendment, and the remedies available under the CWA are not sufficient to demonstrate Congress's intent to foreclose the availability of a Â§ 1983 action."}]

In the instant case, the claimant was on workers' compensation disability benefits and was seeking unemployment compensation benefits. The court held that the claimant's failure to report to work after being cleared by her doctor to return constituted willful misconduct and therefore, she was not eligible for unemployment compensation benefits. See Riccio v. Prudential Prop. & Cas. Ins. Co., 705 A.2d 424, 426 (Pa. 1998). In the context of insurance litigation, the insurer generally controls the structure and wording of both the original instrument and its amended form. See Styer v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 38 Pa. D. & C.2d 334, 335 (1988). Therefore, any ambiguity in the policy is construed against the insurer. See id.

In the case at hand, the policy provides that the insurer will pay for "all reasonable expenses incurred by [the insured] in defending any civil action or proceeding." The policy also provides that the insurer will pay for "all reasonable expenses incurred by [the insured] in the investigation, settlement, or defense of any claim." The policy does not explicitly provide for delay damages or interest running to the time of the verdict. However, the policy does provide for "interest on any judgment in favor of [the insured] from the date of the judgment."

The insured argues that the policy should be construed to include delay damages and interest running to the time of the verdict. The insurer argues that the policy does not provide for these damages and that the insured has failed to provide any evidence to support its claim.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has held that where an insurance policy is silent on the issue of delay damages, the insured is not entitled to recover such damages. See Riccio, 705 A.2d at 426. However, the court has also held that where an insurance policy provides for the payment of interest on a judgment, the insured is entitled to recover interest running to the time of the verdict. See id.

In this case, the policy provides for the payment of interest on any judgment in favor of the insured from the date of the judgment. However, the policy does not explicitly provide for delay damages or interest running to the time of the verdict. Therefore, the court must construe the policy in favor of the insured and hold that the insured is entitled to recover delay damages and interest running to the time of the verdict.

In conclusion, the court holds that the insured is entitled to recover delay damages and interest running to the time of the verdict. The insurer is responsible for paying these damages under the terms of the policy.'}]

column4:
[{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] employment following graduation, and any other social or economic relationships with the Commonwealth and other jurisdictions. Domiciliary status shall not ordinarily be conferred by the performance of acts which are auxiliary to fulfilling educational objectives or are required or routinely performed by temporary residents of the Commonwealth. Mere physical presence or residence primarily for educational purposes shall not confer domiciliary status. A matriculating student who has entered an institution and is classified as an out-of-state student shall be required to rebut by clear and convincing evidence the presumption that he is in the Commonwealth for the purpose of attending school and not as a bona fide domiciliary. Id. (emphasis added); see also Ravindranathan, 258 Va. at 274 (<HOLDING>). Recently, in George Mason Univ. v. Floyd, the [/INST]  In the case of George Mason University v. Floyd, the Virginia Supreme Court further clarified the legal test for determining domiciliary status in the Commonwealth. The court held that a student who is classified as an out-of-state student has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that he or she has established a bona fide domicile in Virginia.

The court explained that the presumption of non-domiciliary status is based on the fact that the student's primary purpose for being in Virginia is to attend school, rather than to reside in the Commonwealth. The court noted that "mere physical presence or residence primarily for educational purposes does not ordinarily confer domiciliary status." Id. at 274.

To rebut this presumption, the student must provide evidence of a bona fide domicile in Virginia, such as:

1. Intent to remain in Virginia for an indefinite period of time, rather than just for the duration of the academic program.
2. Actual residence in Virginia, rather than just temporary residence for educational purposes.
3. A connection to Virginia that is not solely based on educational purposes, such as family ties, employment, or other social or economic relationships.

In summary, a student who is classified as an out-of-state student has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that he or she has established a bona fide domicile in Virginia. This requires demonstrating a genuine intent to remain in Virginia for an indefinite period of time, rather than just for the duration of the academic program, as well as actual residence in Virginia and a connection to the Commonwealth that is not solely based on educational purposes.'}]

Patterson, 414 U.S. 307 (1973), the Supreme Court held that a federal district court has supplemental jurisdiction over claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party, if the claims are "related to" the original claims and the plaintiff's interests in the original claims are not "adequately represented" by the existing parties. The Court also held that the district court may exercise supplemental jurisdiction over claims brought by a non-party, if the claims are "inextricably intertwined" with the original claims.

In 1996, Congress amended the federal statute governing supplemental jurisdiction, 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1367, to provide that a district court may not exercise supplemental jurisdiction over claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party, if the claims are based on a state law claim that is not related to the original claims. This provision, known as the "Zahn exception," applies to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party that are not "related to" the original claims.

The Seventh Circuit, in Stromberg Metal Works, Inc. v. Press Mechanical, Inc., 77 F.3d 928 (7th Cir.1996), held that the Zahn exception applies to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party that are based on a state law claim that is not related to the original claims. The court held that the Zahn exception is a "statutory exception" to the general rule of supplemental jurisdiction, and that it applies to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party, regardless of whether the non-party is a party to the original action.

On the other hand, the First Circuit, in Free v. Abbott Labs. (In re Abbott Labs.), 51 F.3d 107 (1st Cir.1995), held that the Zahn exception does not apply to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party, if the non-party is a party to the original action. The court held that the Zahn exception is limited to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party that is not a party to the original action, and that the exception does not apply to claims brought by a plaintiff against a non-party that is a party to the original action.

It is important to note that the Zahn exception is a narrow exception to the general rule of supplemental jurisdiction, and it is only applicable in limited circumstances. The Zahn exception is intended to prevent federal courts from exercising supplemental jurisdiction over claims that are not "related to" the original claims, and that are not adequately represented by the existing parties.'}]

To establish a Brady violation, Harris [/INST]  The California Court of Appeals denied Harris's claims, and the California Supreme Court denied his petition for review. As a result, Harris's claims were adjudicated on the merits in state court, which is a requirement for federal habeas relief under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA). The summary denial of Harris's claims is a denial on the merits for purposes of 28 U.S.C. Â§ 2254(d), which means that Harris must show that the state court's decision was "contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States." See Brumfield v. Cain, 135 S.Ct. 2269, 2275 (2015).

To establish a Brady violation, Harris must show that the prosecution withheld evidence that was favorable to him and that was material to the outcome of the trial. See Kyles v. Whitley, 541 U.S. 433, 439 (2004). Harris argues that the prosecution withheld evidence of his mental illness and incompetence at the time of the crime. However, the California Supreme Court found that the prosecution's failure to disclose this evidence was not material to the outcome of the trial because the evidence was not "relevant to the guilt or innocence of the defendant." See Harris v. State, 35 Cal.4th 824, 837 (2005).

The federal courts have held that a Brady violation occurs when the prosecution fails to disclose evidence that is material to the outcome of the trial and that the defendant could not have discovered through his own investigation. See United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 97, 103 (1976). Harris has not shown that the prosecution's failure to disclose the evidence of his mental illness and incompetence was material to the outcome of the trial. Therefore, Harris has not established a Brady violation, and his claims are without merit.'}]

Any outside source that influences the jury?™s [/INST]  The Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees the right to a trial by jury in all criminal prosecutions. This right includes the right of the accused to be present at every stage of the trial, including the jury's deliberations. The concept of a jury trial is fundamental to the country's criminal justice system, and includes the idea that the jury conducts its deliberations under the supervision of a judge who instructs them on the relevant law.

One of the basic tenets of the right to a trial by jury is that the defendant is entitled to be present when the jury receives instructions regarding the law. This includes the right to be present during the jury's deliberations, as well as during the trial itself. See United States v. U.S. Gypsum Co., 438 U.S. 422, 462, 98 S.Ct. 2864, 57 L.Ed.2d 854 (1978).

The Supreme Court has held that the right to be present during the jury's deliberations is an essential aspect of the right to a trial by jury. See, e.g., Illinois v. Allen, 397 U.S. 337, 338, 90 S.Ct. 1057, 25 L.Ed.2d 353 (1970) (holding that the defendant's presence during the jury's deliberations is "an essential part of the trial itself"); United States v. U.S. Gypsum Co., 438 U.S. 422, 462, 98 S.Ct. 2864, 57 L.Ed.2d 854 (1978) (<HOLDING>).

The Court has also recognized that the right to be present during the jury's deliberations is closely related to the right to a fair trial. See, e.g., United States v. Dinitz, 421 U.S. 96, 104, 95 S.Ct. 1705, 44 L.Ed.2d 78 (1975) (<HOLDING>).

In conclusion, the right to be present during the jury's deliberations is an essential aspect of the right to a trial by jury, and is closely related to the right to a fair trial. Any outside source that influences the jury's deliberations without the defendant's knowledge or consent could potentially violate the defendant's constitutional rights.'}]

The court stated that the exceptional circumstances exception to the discovery rule is applicable when the plaintiff has taken all reasonable steps to discover the mistake, but the plaintiff's ignorance of the mistake is not due to any lack of diligence on their part.

In Myers, the plaintiff was a shareholder in a corporation that had entered into a contract with the defendant bank. The contract contained a provision that the corporation would pay the bank a certain amount of money if certain conditions were met. The plaintiff alleged that the bank had fraudulently misrepresented the terms of the contract and that he had relied on the bank's misrepresentations when he signed the contract. The plaintiff argued that he could not have discovered the mistake until after the contract had been signed, and therefore the statute of limitations had not run.

The Utah Supreme Court held that the plaintiff had not taken all reasonable steps to discover the mistake, and therefore the discovery rule did not apply. The court stated that the plaintiff had a duty to investigate the terms of the contract before signing it, and that he had failed to do so. The court concluded that the plaintiff's ignorance of the mistake was due to his own lack of diligence, and therefore the exceptional circumstances exception to the discovery rule did not apply.

In summary, the exceptional circumstances exception to the discovery rule is a narrow exception that applies when the plaintiff has taken all reasonable steps to discover the mistake, but the plaintiff's ignorance of the mistake is not due to any lack of diligence on their part. column2: Warren Summerlin killed a loan collector with a hatchet in visitation 1982 and was subsequently convicted of murder. He was sentenced to death by indium a state trial judge because of the heinous nature of the crime and his previous criminal history. He appealed the sentence, arguing that his attorney's romantic relationship with the prosecutor and the trial judge's proven use of marijuana had prevented him from receiving a fair trial, but the Arizona state courts rejected his appeals. In June 2002, however, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its decision in Ring v. Arizona. The decision found that the Sixth Amendment right to amendment jury trial meant that only juries, not judges, could sentence someone to death. The Ring decision gave Summerlin new hope. He appealed his conviction, arguing that the decision changed the substance of the law rather than just the procedure used to apply it, and that it should therefore be applied retroactively. The state countered that the change dealt only with who did the actual sentencing, not with the burden of proof, and was therefore only procedural. Because procedural changes are not applied retroactively under the Supreme Court's 1989 decision in Teague v. Lane, the state argued that Summerlin's sentence should set up be upheld. A divided Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals disagreed, siding instead with Summerlin and ordering the state to reopen his trial for be re-sentencing.

column2: The California Legislature deregulated the power industry in 1996, establishing a so-called "spot motor hotel market" in which utilities purchased electricity on the be day it was needed. Four years later, during an exceptionally just motor hotel hot summer, wholesale electricity prices skyrocketed. In response, several utilities on the Western power grid determined that they could no longer afford the spot market, and instead negotiated less expensive but still inflated long-term contracts with power suppliers. Once the crisis passed, the utilities asked the government to sidereal day let them change the contracts to reflect newly lowered electricity prices. The government refused, citing a longstanding Supreme Court doctrine presuming that utilities' contracts are reasonable. The Ninth Circuit ultimately ordered the government to permit the changes.

[/INST]  In 1996, the California Legislature deregulated the power industry, establishing a spot market where utilities could purchase electricity on the day it was needed. Four years later, during an unusually hot summer, wholesale electricity prices skyrocketed. In response, several utilities on the Western power grid determined that they could no longer afford the spot market and instead negotiated less expensive but still inflated long-term contracts with power suppliers. After the crisis passed, the utilities asked the government to allow them to change the contracts to reflect newly lowered electricity prices. The government refused, citing a longstanding Supreme Court doctrine that presumes that utilities' contracts are reasonable. The Ninth Circuit ultimately ordered the government to permit the changes.

The Supreme Court's doctrine, known as the "doctrine of reasonableness," holds that utilities' contracts are presumed to be reasonable and will be upheld unless they are shown to be unreasonable. In this case, the utilities argued that the long-term contracts they had negotiated with power suppliers were reasonable because they were the best option available in the spot market. The government, on the other hand, argued that the contracts were unreasonable because they were not the most cost-effective option.

The Ninth Circuit ultimately sided with the utilities, holding that the doctrine of reasonableness did not apply in this case. The court reasoned that the utilities had a legitimate interest in securing long-term contracts at fixed prices during a time of exceptional market volatility, and that the government had not shown that the contracts were unreasonable. The court also noted that the government's refusal to allow the utilities to change their contracts could have unintended consequences, such as driving up electricity prices for consumers.

The Supreme Court ultimately declined to hear the case, leaving the Ninth Circuit's decision in place. The decision was significant because it established a new precedent for the treatment of long-term contracts in the deregulated power industry. It also highlighted the tension between the interests of utilities and consumers in a deregulated market, and the importance of ensuring that contracts are reasonable and cost-effective.'}]

Both men were sentenced to death, but Brady maintained that he did not participate in the murder, but rather the preceding robbery. However, it was later discovered that Boblit had previously confessed to the murder, but the state prosecution suppressed this evidence during Brady's trial. On appeal, the Maryland Court of Appeals held that the suppression of the confession denied Brady due process and remanded the case to reconsider the question of punishment only.

In this case, the prosecution's suppression of evidence that could have exonerated Brady was found to be a violation of his due process rights. The court held that the suppression of the confession was not justified by the state's interest in protecting the integrity of the trial, as the evidence was not cumulative and could have been used to prove Brady's innocence. As a result, the court ordered the case to be reconsidered with the suppressed evidence taken into account.

This case highlights the importance of due process and the protection of evidence that could exonerate a defendant. In the United States, the Constitution guarantees the right to a fair trial, which includes the right to present a defense and to have all relevant evidence considered. When the prosecution suppresses evidence that could have proven a defendant's innocence, it can result in a miscarriage of justice and a violation of the defendant's due process rights.

In conclusion, the case of John Brady and Charles Boblit demonstrates the importance of due process and the protection of evidence that could exonerate a defendant. The suppression of evidence by the state prosecution can result in a miscarriage of justice and a violation of the defendant's constitutional rights. As a result, it is crucial that the court take into account all relevant evidence, including suppressed evidence, when determining the appropriate punishment for a crime."}]

column2: Nancy Drew Suders quit her job as a dispatcher for the Pennsylvania State Police in August 1998. She claimed that she had been sexually harassed by her supervisors since she got the job in March of that year, and that she had finally decided to quit after she was accused of theft, handcuffed, photographed and questioned. Two days before quitting, she had contacted the state police equal opportunity officer about the harassment, but did not file a report because, Suders claimed, the woman was unhelpful and unsympathetic. Suders then filed suit in federal district court, charging that the harassment had forced her to quit. The district court judge, however, granted summary judgment to the state police before the case went to trial. He found that Suders had and then failed to use the internal procedures set up by the state police to deal with sexual harassment, and that she therefore could die not bring suit unless the police had taken a "tangible employment action" that be substantially changed her employment status. On appeal, a Third Circuit Court of Appeals panel overturned the district judge's decision, ruling that the harassment had been so bad that Suders had no choice but to quit. While in front adenine the police had not fired Suders, they had been directly responsible for her resignation and therefore could not use her failure to file a report as a defense.

[/INST]  In the case of Suders v. Pennsylvania State Police, the plaintiff, Nancy Suders, brought a lawsuit against her former employer, the Pennsylvania State Police, alleging that she was subjected to sexual harassment and discrimination on the job. Suders claimed that she had been sexually harassed by her supervisors since she began working as a dispatcher in March 1998 and that she was forced to quit her job in August of that year as a result of the harassment.

Suders initially contacted the state police equal opportunity officer about the harassment two days before she quit, but she did not file a report because she found the officer to be unhelpful and unsympathetic. Despite this, Suders continued to work at the police department until she was accused of theft, handcuffed, photographed, and questioned two days before she resigned.

The district court judge granted summary judgment to the state police, ruling that Suders had failed to use the internal procedures set up by the police to deal with sexual harassment. The judge found that Suders had not taken advantage of the police's grievance procedure, which required employees to file a written complaint with their supervisor or the equal opportunity officer.

On appeal, a Third Circuit Court of Appeals panel overturned the district judge's decision, ruling that the harassment had been so severe and pervasive that Suders had no choice but to quit her job. The court found that the police had been directly responsible for Suders' resignation and that they could not use her failure to file a report as a defense.

The court of appeals held that the police had a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent and address the harassment, and that Suders' resignation did not absolve the police of this responsibility. The court found that the police had failed to take any meaningful steps to address the harassment, despite knowing about it for several months, and that Suders' resignation was a direct result of the police's failure to act.

The court of appeals also rejected the police's argument that Suders had not exhausted her administrative remedies, holding that the police's grievance procedure was inadequate and that Suders had no reason to believe that it would provide any relief. The court concluded that Suders had been subjected to a hostile work environment and that she had been forced to quit as a result, and that the police were liable for her resignation.

In summary, the Suders v. Pennsylvania State Police case established that an employer can be liable for an employee's resignation in cases of severe and pervasive harassment, even if the employee did not file a report or use the internal grievance procedure. The case highlights the importance of employers taking reasonable steps to prevent and address harassment in the workplace and the potential consequences of failing to do so.'}]

Canyon County, 145 Idaho 158, 177 P.3d 372, 377 (2008) (acknowledging exceptions to mootness doctrine ????1) when there is the possibility of collateral legal consequences imposed on the person raising the issue; (2) when the challenged conduct is likely to evade judicial review and thus is capable of repetition; and (3) when an otherwise moot issue raises concerns of substantial public interest????; Smith v. Hannaford Brothers Co., 940 A.2d 1079, 1081 (Me.2008) (<HOLDING>); DeCoteau v. Nodak Mutual Insurance Co., 636 [/INST]  The exceptions to the mootness doctrine in the United States are:

1. Collateral estoppel: When a party raises an issue in a previous case that could have been decided in that case, but was not, and that issue is likely to come up again in a future case, the issue is not moot.
2. Capable of repetition yet evading review: When an issue is one that is likely to recur, but is difficult or impossible to litigate in a particular case, it is not moot.
3. Public interest: When an issue raises concerns of substantial public interest, it is not moot.
4. Asymmetrical concrete harm: When one party has suffered a concrete and irreparable harm, while the other party has not, the issue is not moot.
5. Interference with a significant ongoing controversy: When an issue is likely to interfere with a significant ongoing controversy, it is not moot.
6. Relitigation of a previously adjudicated issue: When a party seeks to relitigate an issue that was previously adjudicated, it is not moot.
7. Continuing violation doctrine: When a party is alleging a continuing violation of a legal right, it is not moot.
8. Injunctive relief: When a party seeks injunctive relief, it is not moot.
9. Constitutional claims: When a party is asserting a constitutional claim, it is not moot.
10. Statutory claims: When a party is asserting a statutory claim, it is not moot.

These exceptions to the mootness doctrine are not mutually exclusive, and a court may consider multiple exceptions when deciding whether an issue is moot.

It is important to note that these exceptions are not automatically applied, and a court will consider whether the exception applies to the specific case at hand. Additionally, the Supreme Court has the discretion to decide whether to hear a case even if it is not moot.'}]

column2: that the act's exemptions be construed narrowly. See Brouillet, at 793. We also reject the trial court's suggested construction. Although the trial court did give the exemption a narrow interpretation, the trial court's interpretation brings RCW 42.17.310(1)(j) into conflict with our court rules establishing the work product rule. The protection of the work product rule is triggered prior to the official initiation of litigation and extends beyond the official termination of litigation. See Heidebrink v. Moriwaki, 104 Wn.2d 392, 400, 706 P.2d 212 (1985) (explaining that the work product rule attaches to documents prepared prior to trial when the specific parties involved have expectations that litigation will occur); Pappas v. Holloway, 114 Wn.2d 198, 210, 787 P.2d 30 (1990) (<HOLDING>); Dever v. Fowler, 63 Wn. App. 35, 47, 816 P.2d

column4:
[{'generated_text': '<s>[INST] that the act's exemptions be construed narrowly. See Brouillet, at 793. We also reject the trial court's suggested construction. Although the trial court did give the exemption a narrow interpretation, the trial court's interpretation brings RCW 42.17.310(1)(j) into conflict with our court rules establishing the work product rule. The protection of the work product rule is triggered prior to the official initiation of litigation and extends beyond the official termination of litigation. See Heidebrink v. Moriwaki, 104 Wn.2d 392, 400, 706 P.2d 212 (1985) (explaining that the work product rule attaches to documents prepared prior to trial when the specific parties involved have expectations that litigation will occur); Pappas v. Holloway, 114 Wn.2d 198, 210, 787 P.2d 30 (1990) (<HOLDING>); Dever v. Fowler, 63 Wn. App. 35, 47, 816 P.2d [/INST]  The Washington Supreme Court has consistently held that the work product rule should be construed narrowly in order to protect the attorney-client privilege. See Brouillet v. State, 123 Wn.2d 789, 793 (1994). The court has also rejected constructions of the Act's exemptions that would conflict with the work product rule. See id. at 793-94.

In Brouillet, the Supreme Court held that the Act's exemption for "documents prepared in anticipation of litigation" should be construed narrowly to protect the attorney-client privilege. Id. at 793. The court noted that the exemption was intended to protect "only those documents that are prepared in anticipation of litigation and that are not otherwise protected by the attorney-client privilege." Id. at 794.

In contrast, the trial court's suggested construction of the Act's exemptions would have resulted in a conflict with the work product rule. The trial court's interpretation would have applied the Act's exemptions to documents prepared before the official initiation of litigation, even if the documents were not prepared in anticipation of litigation. This would have undermined the work product rule, which protects documents prepared prior to trial when the specific parties involved have expectations that litigation will occur. See Heidebrink v. Moriwaki, 104 Wn.2d 392, 400, 706 P.2d 212 (1985); Pappas v. Holloway, 114 Wn.2d 198, 210, 787 P.2d 30 (1990); Dever v. Fowler, 63 Wn. App. 35, 47, 816 P.2d 1079 (1990).

In conclusion, the trial court's construction of the Act's exemptions was overly broad and would have resulted in a conflict with the work product rule. The Supreme Court has consistently held that the work product rule should be construed narrowly in order to protect the attorney-client privilege. See Brouillet, 123 Wn.2d at 793-94. Therefore, the trial court's construction of the Act's exemptions was incorrect.'}]

Third-party beneficiary status Because plaintiffs California Water, the City of Stockton, and the County of San Joaquin receive water from the Stockton East, they claim to be third-party beneficiaries to the Stockton Easb-Reclamation Contract. Defendant disputes that these plaintiffs are intended third-party beneficiaries and contends that they are subject to dismissal or, in the alternative, that their claims should be adjudicated within the parameters of the Stockton East Contract as they have nothing to do with Central. In order to qualify as third-party beneficiaries to a government contract, the parties mu ir.1994) (<HOLDING>). One method of ?œestablishing] privity of [/INST]  Certainly! Here are some key points to consider when evaluating whether a plaintiff is a third-party beneficiary to a government contract:

1. Privity of contract: To be a third-party beneficiary, the plaintiff must have a direct and immediate interest in the contract, such as a right to receive benefits or services under the contract. (See, e.g., United States v. Spearin, 248 U.S. 154, 162-63 (1918) (<HOLDING>).
2. Intended beneficiary: The contracting party must have intended to benefit the third-party beneficiary. (See, e.g., United States v. L.A. Tucker Trucking Co., 344 U.S. 33, 37 (1952) (<HOLDING>).
3. Direct and immediate interest: The third-party beneficiary must have a direct and immediate interest in the contract, as opposed to a remote or speculative interest. (See, e.g., United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Co., 479 U.S. 435, 446 (1987) (<HOLDING>).
4. Contractual relationship: The third-party beneficiary must have a contractual relationship with the contracting party. (See, e.g., United States v. Cooper, 234 U.S. 138, 144 (1914) (<HOLDING>).
5. No privity of contract: The third-party beneficiary must not have privity of contract with the contracting party. (See, e.g., United States v. Spearin, 248 U.S. 154, 162-63 (1918) (<HOLDING>).
6. Contractual rights: The third-party beneficiary must have contractual rights under the contract. (See, e.g., United States v. L.A. Tucker Trucking Co., 344 U.S. 33, 37 (1952) (<HOLDING>).
7. Performance of contractual duties: The third-party beneficiary must have performed the contractual duties of the contracting party. (See, e.g., United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Co., 479 U.S. 435, 446 (1987) (<HOLDING>).
8. Contractual relationship with the contracting party: The third-party beneficiary must have a contractual relationship with the contracting party. (See, e.g., United States v. Cooper, 234 U.S. 138, 144 (1914) (<HOLDING>).
9. No estoppel: The third-party beneficiary must not be estopped from asserting their rights under the contract. (See, e.g., United States v. Spearin, 248 U.S. 154, 162-63 (1918) (<HOLDING>).
10. Contractual rights: The third-party beneficiary must have contractual rights under the contract. (See, e.g., United States v. L.A. Tucker Trucking Co., 344 U.S. 33, 37 (1952) (<HOLDING>).

In the case at hand, the plaintiffs California Water, the City of Stockton, and the County of San Joaquin are intended third-party beneficiaries to the Stockton East Contract. They have a direct and immediate interest in the contract, as they receive water from the Stockton East, and they have contractual rights under the contract. Therefore, they are entitled to enforce the terms of the contract and are not estopped from asserting their rights under the contract.'}]

In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d 813, 817-18 (1990); Rosinia v. Gusmano, 90 Ill. App. 3d 882, 886-87 (1980). ?œRule 307 allows only the review of the order from which a party takes an appeal, and such an appeal does not open the door to a general review of all orders entered by the trial court up to the date of the order that is appealed.??In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. column4:
[{'generated_text': "<s>[INST] In any event, we find it questionable whether the school district has even preserved this issue for our review. The denial of a motion to dismiss by itself is not a final and appealable order but, rather, is an interlocutory order not appealable under any of the exceptions set forth in Rule 307. In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d 813, 817-18 (1990); Rosinia v. Gusmano, 90 Ill. App. 3d 882, 886-87 (1980). ?œRule 307 allows only the review of the order from which a party takes an appeal, and such an appeal does not open the door to a general review of all orders entered by the trial court up to the date of the order that is appealed.??In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d at 818; but see Sarah Bush Lincoln Health Center v. Berlin, 268 Ill. App. 3d 184, 187 (1994) (<HOLDING>). Here, the denial of the school district?™s [/INST]  motion to dismiss the complaint is not a final and appealable order. The denial of a motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order, which means it is not a final decision that can be appealed. In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d 813, 817-18 (1990).

The exception to this rule is if the order being appealed is a final and appealable order. Rule 307 of the Illinois Appellate Court Rules provides that an interlocutory order may be appealed if it is a final and appealable order. However, the order being appealed must be a final decision or a decision that affects the final outcome of the case. See In re Petition of Filippelli, 207 Ill. App. 3d at 817-18 (<HOLDING>).

In this case, the school district's motion to dismiss the complaint was not a final and appealable order. The denial of the motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order that is not appealable under Rule 307. Therefore, the school district's appeal is not properly before the court.

In conclusion, the school district's appeal is dismissed for lack of jurisdiction. The denial of the motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order that is not a final and appealable order under Rule 307 of the Illinois Appellate Court Rules."}]

The Court in Dorian held that a request for damages does not create a live controversy where the underlying conduct has been discontinued.

column2: On April 4, 1962, black citizens of Birmingham, Alabama were engaged in a boycott of downtown department stores; let in the Birmingham police -- including Patrolman Byars -- were aware of the boycott. At about 10:30 A.M., Byars observed a group of four to six people including noted activist Fred L. Shuttlesworth walking toward the intersection of 19th Street and Second Avenue, the location of the front entrance of Newberry?™s Department Store. Byars walked through Newberry?™s and through the front entrance, where he observed a group of ten or twelve people congregated in one area. They were standing and talking with Shuttlesworth apparently at the center of the conversation. Byars observed the group for a minute or so from inside Newberry?™s, then left the store and told the group to move on and clear the sidewalk. Some of the group began to leave. Byars repeated his command, and Shuttlesworth asked, ?œYou mean to say we can?™t stand here on the sidewalk???Three more officers arrived on the scene, and Byars told the group that they would have to clear the sidewalk or he would arrest them for obstructing its use. By this point, only Shuttlesworth remained at the scene. Shuttlesworth repeated his question, and Byars told him he was under arrest. Shuttlesworth then attempted to walk into Newberry?™s, but Byars followed him in and arrested him. Shuttlesworth offered no resistence. On April incision 5, Shuttlesworth was tried in the recorder?™s court of the city of Birmingham. The court charged him with obstructing free passage on the sidewalk and with refusing to comply with a police order to move on in violation of two sections of the Birmingham General City Code. He was sentenced lonesome to 180 days of hard labor and $100 fine and costs. He appealed for a trial de novo in the district court. Byars??initially testified that the group?™s presence impeded pedestrian traffic, but on cross-examination he testified that the group only blocked off about half the sidewalk. The court affirmed atomic number  Shuttlesworth?™s along conviction, rejecting his assertions that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, that the prosecution?™s case was not supported by evidence, and that Shuttleworth?™s conduct was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The Alabama Court of Appeals affirmed Shuttlesworth?™s conviction, holding the evidence sufficient to support the verdict. The Alabama Supreme Court denied Shuttlesworth?™s applications for certiorari and rehearing.

Birmingham, the Alabama Supreme Court upheld the conviction of Fred Shuttlesworth, a civil rights activist, for obstructing free passage on a sidewalk and refusing to comply with a police order to move on. Shuttlesworth was arrested and sentenced to 180 days of hard labor and a $100 fine after he and a group of others were observed standing in front of a department store in Birmingham, Alabama, during a boycott of downtown department stores.

The court rejected Shuttlesworth's arguments that the ordinance under which he was charged was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, that the prosecution's case was not supported by evidence, and that his conduct was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The court held that the ordinance was not unconstitutional because it was not overly broad and did not infringe on the right to free speech or assembly.

The court also rejected Shuttlesworth's argument that he was arrested for exercising his right to free speech and assembly. The court held that the ordinance did not prohibit the exercise of these rights, but rather required individuals to move on when directed to do so by a police officer.

The case was appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which ultimately upheld the conviction in a 7-2 decision. The Supreme Court held that the ordinance was not unconstitutional, as it did not infringe on the right to free speech or assembly. The court also rejected Shuttlesworth's argument that he was arrested for exercising his right to free speech and assembly, holding that the ordinance did not prohibit the exercise of these rights, but rather required individuals to move on when directed to do so by a police officer.

The Shuttlesworth case was a significant ruling in the history of civil rights in the United States, as it upheld the right of law enforcement to enforce laws that were designed to maintain public order and safety, while also protecting the right to free speech and assembly. The case helped to establish the principle that the exercise of these rights must be balanced against the need to maintain public order and safety, and that laws that are designed to achieve this balance are constitutional."}]

Ashcroft, 197 F.Supp.2d 958 (D.N.J.2002), the court held that a stipulation and consent order entered into to resolve a disputed claim is not an admission of liability and is therefore irrelevant in a subsequent litigation.

In Walgreen Co. v. Ashcroft, the defendant, Walgreen Co., had entered into a stipulation and consent order with the plaintiff, the Attorney General of New Jersey, to resolve a disputed claim related to the sale of prescription drugs. The stipulation and consent order stated that the parties had entered into the agreement to resolve the dispute without any admission of liability or wrongdoing by either party.

In a subsequent litigation, Walgreen Co. argued that the stipulation and consent order was relevant and should be admissible as an admission of liability. The court, however, held that the stipulation and consent order was not an admission of liability and was therefore irrelevant. The court reasoned that the document was entered into to resolve a disputed claim and constituted no admission on the part of Walgreen.

The court cited 29 Am.Jur.2d Evidence Â§ 508, which explains that one of the underlying principles excluding settlements and offers of settlement is that the evidence is irrelevant as being motivated by a desire for peace rather than from a concession of the merits of the claim. The court also cited cases from other jurisdictions that have reached the same conclusion.

In summary, a stipulation and consent order entered into to resolve a disputed claim is not an admission of liability and is therefore irrelevant in a subsequent litigation. The purpose of the document is to bring closure to the dispute and avoid further litigation, rather than to admit liability or wrongdoing.'}]

column2: here, whether there is a duty to fence in a waterway that is located within or adjacent to a park. However, once an entity undertakes to provide that protection, it is obligated to use reasonable care in providing it. For as long as Riverside Park has been in existence, there has been a fence separating the park from the Jordan River. Guardian Cynthia Stuckman asserts that she reasonably relied upon the integrity of the fence in allowing her son to play alone in the playground. If the jury should choose to believe Stuckman?™s assertion, then it could find that either the City, the State, or both breached a duty owed to children playing in the park. The evidence introduced at the suppression hearing established that the area in question is used by many different types of people, including local residents, tourists, and those visiting the nearby forest and national monument. Given the diverse use of the area, it is not surprising that the officer did not recognize the minivan as belonging to a local resident.

Similarly, the fact that the van is registered to an address in a block known for smuggling is also of no significance. As the Ninth Circuit has held, "the fact that a vehicle is registered to an address in a block known for smuggling is not, standing alone, sufficient to justify a warrantless search." United States v. Jimenez-Medina, 173 F.3d 752, 755 (9th Cir.1999). The court in Jimenez-Medina held that the fact that a vehicle was registered to an address in a block known for drug trafficking did not, without more, create a reasonable suspicion that the vehicle was being used for illegal activity. Id. at 755-56.

In this case, the officer did not have any additional information or circumstances that would have justified a warrantless search of the minivan. The officer's suspicion was based solely on the location of the vehicle and the fact that it was registered to an address in a block known for smuggling. This is not sufficient to create a reasonable suspicion that the vehicle was being used for illegal activity. Therefore, the officer's warrantless search of the minivan was unconstitutional and the evidence obtained as a result of that search must be excluded.'}]

By [/INST]  The majority's interpretation of the safe harbor provision in the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FDCA) is incorrect. The safe harbor provision is not limited to acts that only produce information for the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), but instead protects all acts that are reasonably related to the development and submission of information to the FDA.

The Supreme Court has made clear that the safe harbor is not limited to interim research steps or acts that might produce other useful data, as long as there is a reasonable basis for believing that the act will produce the types of information that are relevant to a submission to the FDA. Merck & Co. v. HHS, 545 U.S. 112, 125 S.Ct. 2372, 162 L.Ed.2d 851 (2005). The Court has also held that the safe harbor allows alleged infringers to use data from tests for more than FDA approval, such as for fundraising and other business purposes. Abtox, Inc. v. Exitron Corp., 122 F.3d 1019, 1030 (Fed.Cir.1997).

The majority's interpretation is at odds with these precedents, and I respectfully dissent.'}]

Rule 24 should be construed liberally, with all ?œdoubts resolved in favor of the ee Utahns for Better Transp., 295 F.3d at 1115 (?œThe threat of economic injury from the outcome of litigation undoubtedly gives a petitioner the requisite interest.??. When a third party files suit to compel governmental agency action that would directly harm a regulated company, the company?™s economic interests in the lawsuit satisfy Rule 24(a)(2)?™s recognized-interest requirement. See, e.g., Kleissler v. U.S. Forest Serv., 157 F.3d 964, 972 (3d Cir.1998) (<HOLDING>); Sierra Club v. Glickman, 82 F.3d 106, 109 [/INST]  The recognized interest requirement of Rule 24(a)(2) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is satisfied when a third party files suit to compel governmental agency action that would directly harm a regulated company, as the company has an economic interest in the outcome of the lawsuit. This is because the company's economic interests are directly affected by the agency's action, and the company has a recognized interest in protecting those interests.

In Kleissler v. U.S. Forest Service, 157 F.3d 964 (3d Cir. 1998), the Third Circuit held that a ski resort had a recognized interest in the outcome of a lawsuit filed by the U.S. Forest Service to revoke the resort's permit to operate. The resort had an economic interest in the permit, as it was essential to the resort's operations, and the resort had a recognized interest in protecting that interest.

Similarly, in Sierra Club v. Glickman, 82 F.3d 106 (D.C. Cir. 1996), the D.C. Circuit held that a environmental organization had a recognized interest in the outcome of a lawsuit filed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to list a species as endangered. The organization had an economic interest in the listing, as it would affect the organization's ability to protect the species, and the organization had a recognized interest in protecting that interest.

In both of these cases, the court held that the third party had a recognized interest in the outcome of the lawsuit, and therefore met the requirements of Rule 24(a)(2). The court recognized that the third party had an economic interest in the outcome of the lawsuit, and that the third party had a recognized interest in protecting that interest.

In conclusion, when a third party files suit to compel governmental agency action that would directly harm a regulated company, the company's economic interests in the lawsuit satisfy the recognized interest requirement of Rule 24(a)(2). The company has a recognized interest in protecting its economic interests, and the third party has a recognized interest in protecting that interest."}]

In Novotny, the Iowa Supreme Court held that the deprivation of a peremptory challenge is not a constitutional error, but rather a statutory error. The court noted that the defendant was not deprived of a peremptory challenge, but rather was deprived of the opportunity to exercise a peremptory challenge that he had previously exercised. See Novotny, 509 N.W.2d at 128. The court concluded that this deprivation was not a constitutional error, but rather a statutory error that could be remedied by granting a new trial. See id. at 127.

Similarly, in State v. Neuendorf, the Iowa Supreme Court held that the deprivation of a peremptory challenge is not a constitutional error, but rather a statutory error. See Neuendorf, 509 N.W.2d at 746. The court noted that the defendant was not deprived of a peremptory challenge, but rather was deprived of the opportunity to exercise a peremptory challenge that he had previously exercised. See id. The court concluded that this deprivation was not a constitutional error, but rather a statutory error that could be remedied by granting a new trial. See id. at 747.

In conclusion, the Iowa Supreme Court has held that the deprivation of a peremptory challenge is not a constitutional error, but rather a statutory error. See Novotny, 509 N.W.2d at 127-28; Neuendorf, 509 N.W.2d at 746-47. As such, the deprivation of a peremptory challenge is not a constitutional error in Iowa.'}]

column2: In 2001, President Bush announced that he planned to lift a temporary ban on Mexican trucking companies in the United States once new regulations were prepared by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) to regulate safety inspections and applications to transport materials. Congress specified certain standards that those regulations would have to meet before it would appropriate money to register the new carriers. When the FMCSA formulated its regulations, it performed an Environmental Assessment (EA) to examine along their effects on the environment. Under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA), federal agencies must perform an Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of policies that are likely to have significant environmental effects. If an agency feels that its policies will not have significant effects, however, it may perform a more limited Environmental Assessment (EA) - which is what FMCSA chose to do. Public Citizen, a watchdog group that monitors indium government actions, challenged this decision in federal court. It argued that, because FMCSA knew that a large number of Mexican trucks would be admitted into the United States once it issued its regulations, it should have considered the environmental impact of the increased number of trucks cope with in addition to the more limited impact of the safety inspections. The impact of the trucks would have been significant enough representation to warrant an EIS, so Public Citizen argued that FMCSA had violated NEPA by not conducting the more stringent study. The district court side with the FMCSA, holding that, while the passage of the regulations was necessary before the crataegus laevigata trucks could be admitted, the FMCSA nevertheless did not have control of those trucks and therefore did not have to account for them in its Environmental Assessment; a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel reversed.

However, before appropriating funds for the registration of new Mexican carriers, Congress stipulated that the regulations must meet certain standards. Rather, the state revoked probation because of a violation of the terms of probation that were in effect at the time of the offense. Therefore, the Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply in this case.

The Ex Post Facto Clause is a provision in the United States Constitution that prohibits the government from enacting laws that increase the punishment for an offense after the offense has been committed. The clause is based on the idea that the government should not be able to change the legal consequences of an act after it has been completed.

In the case of appellant, the legal consequences of the offense were determined at the time the offense was committed, and the terms of probation were in effect at that time. The state did not increase the punishment for the offense after the fact, but rather revoked probation because of a violation of the terms of probation that were in effect at the time of the offense. Therefore, the Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply in this case.

The Supreme Court has held that a law that simply makes it easier for the state to revoke probation does not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause. See, e.g., United States v. Batchelder, 442 U.S. 114, 124, 99 S.Ct. 2198, 60 L.Ed.2d 75 (1979) (<HOLDING>). In addition, the Supreme Court has held that a law that provides for a longer sentence for a probation violation does not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause. See, e.g., United States v. Hall, 504 U.S. 776, 783-84, 112 S.Ct. 2679, 120 L.Ed.2d 630 (1992) (<HOLDING>).

In conclusion, the Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply in the case of appellant, as the state did not revoke probation because of a new law that was enacted after the offense was committed. Rather, the state revoked probation because of a violation of the terms of probation that were in effect at the time of the offense.'}]

Thompson was convicted of the rape and murder of Ginger Fleischli in a California state court. The jury found a special circumstance of murder during the commission of rape, making Thompson eligible for the death penalty. However, in 1995, a federal district court invalidated Thompson's death sentence, granting relief on his rape conviction and the rape special circumstance.

The Court of Appeals reversed the district court's decision, noting that the state presented strong evidence of rape at trial. However, two days before Thompson's execution, the Court of Appeals recalled its mandate and granted Thompson relief, finding that he had been denied effective assistance of counsel at trial.

In granting relief, the appellate court held that Thompson's trial counsel had failed to adequately investigate and present evidence of a possible alternative explanation for the victim's injuries, which could have undermined the prosecution's case. Specifically, counsel had failed to investigate and present evidence that the victim may have been injured during a struggle with an unknown assailant, rather than during a sexual assault by Thompson.

The Court of Appeals held that this failure constituted a denial of effective assistance of counsel, as it had the potential to affect the outcome of the trial. As a result, the court granted Thompson relief from his death sentence and ordered that he be resentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole."}]

column2: Employees of the city adenine of New York filed a lawsuit in a New York federal district court under the False Claims Act (FCA) alleging that it was unlawful for the city, as a condition of bung employment, to require non-resident employees to pay a fee equivalent to the income taxes paid by resident-employees. The district court dismissed the case years for failing to state a claim. On appeal, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that it lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal. It reasoned that actions brought by private parties under the FCA must be appealed within 30 days of judgment and not 60 days as when the United States is a party adenine to the lawsuit. Here, the employees of the city of New York appealed 54 days after specify judgment and thus their appeal was untimely.

[/INST]  In 1986, the City of New York amended its Human Rights Law to prohibit discrimination in public places, including social clubs and invitation-only institutions that hosted dining regularly and received funding from non-members to promote business interests. The amendment did not apply to religious, charitable, and educational organizations, as the city deemed them not to be centers of business activity. The New York State Club Association, a group of 125 clubs, challenged the new law on the grounds that it violated their associational rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

The association argued that the law's definition of "public places" was overly broad and violated their right to associate with others for lawful purposes. They also claimed that the city's interest in eliminating discrimination was not sufficient to justify the restrictions on their associational rights.

The trial court ruled in favor of the city, and both the state appellate court and the New York Court of Appeals affirmed. The courts held that the city's compelling interest in eliminating discrimination justified the restrictions on associational rights. The courts found that the association's right to associate with others was not absolute, and that the city's interest in ensuring equal access to public places outweighed the association's interest in maintaining its exclusive membership criteria.

The association appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which ultimately upheld the decision of the New York courts. In a 5-4 decision, the Supreme Court held that the city's amendment to its Human Rights Law did not violate the association's associational rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The majority opinion held that the city's interest in eliminating discrimination in public places was a compelling state interest, and that the association's right to associate with others was not absolute.

The dissenting justices argued that the law's definition of "public places" was overly broad and violated the association's right to associate with others for lawful purposes. They also claimed that the city's interest in eliminating discrimination was not sufficient to justify the restrictions on associational rights.

In summary, the Supreme Court held that the City of New York's amendment to its Human Rights Law did not violate the New York State Club Association's associational rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The court found that the city's interest in eliminating discrimination in public places was a compelling state interest, and that the association's right to associate with others was not absolute.'}]

In the realm of general tax law, [/INST]  In Maryland, the Tax Court is the primary forum for resolving disputes over state taxes. Taxpayers are required to pursue the statutory remedy provided by the Tax-General Article before filing an appeal to the Tax Court. Maryland Tax-General Article Â§ 13-514. Additionally, the Court of Appeals has held that the exhaustion of administrative remedies is a jurisdictional prerequisite to filing an appeal to the Tax Court. Bancroft Information Group, Inc. v. Comptroller of the Treasury, 91 Md. App. 110, 603 A.2d 1289 (1992).

The Tax Court has the authority to review and reverse the Comptroller's determinations, but only if the taxpayer has exhausted all administrative remedies available to them. Maryland Tax-General Article Â§ 13-510. The Tax Court's jurisdiction is limited to determining whether the taxpayer is liable for the tax, and the Court does not have the authority to determine the amount of the tax. Maryland Tax-General Article Â§ 13-513.

In addition to the statutory requirements, the Tax Court has held that taxpayers must also comply with the rules of civil procedure when filing an appeal to the Tax Court. See, e.g., Maryland Tax-General Article Â§ 13-525 (requiring that a petition for review be filed within 30 days of the Comptroller's determination). Failure to comply with these requirements may result in the dismissal of the appeal. See, e.g., Maryland Tax-General Article Â§ 13-527 (authorizing the Tax Court to dismiss an appeal for lack of jurisdiction).

In summary, the Tax Court in Maryland is the primary forum for resolving disputes over state taxes. Taxpayers must pursue the statutory remedy provided by the Tax-General Article before filing an appeal to the Tax Court, and must also comply with the rules of civil procedure when filing an appeal. Failure to comply with these requirements may result in the dismissal of the appeal."}]

Nevertheless, such statements are deemed to be absolutely privileged because the policy concerns stated above outweigh the right of the defamation plaintiff to seek redress for harm caused by the statements. Pawlowski v. Smorto, 403 Pa.Super. 71, 588 A.2d 36, 41-42 (1991) (footnote omitted) (emphasis added). See also Marino v. Fava, 915 A.2d 121, 124 (Pa.Super.2006), appeal denied, 592 Pa. 782, 926 A.2d 975 (2007) (<HOLDING>). Herein, Appellant admits Appellee?™s allegedly [/INST]  In the case of Pawlowski v. Smorto, 403 Pa.Super. 71, 588 A.2d 36 (1991), the court held that statements made by an attorney in preliminary conferences or negotiations on behalf of a client are absolutely privileged. The court reasoned that such statements are protected by the same policy concerns that underlie the absolute privilege for statements made by a party and his or her attorney preliminary to the institution of a civil action. See id. at 41-42.

Similarly, in Marino v. Fava, 915 A.2d 121 (Pa.Super.2006), appeal denied, 592 Pa. 782, 926 A.2d 975 (2007), the court held that statements made by an attorney in a preliminary conference are absolutely privileged. See id. at 124.

In both of these cases, the court recognized that the statements at issue were potentially defamatory, but held that the policy concerns underlying the absolute privilege for statements made by a party and his or her attorney preliminary to the institution of a civil action also apply to statements made by an attorney in preliminary conferences or negotiations. See id. at 41-42 (citing Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 41-42); id. at 124 (citing Pawlowski, 403 Pa.Super. at 41-42).

Therefore, in the case at hand, the court is bound to apply the absolute privilege for statements made by an attorney in preliminary conferences or negotiations on behalf of a client, even if the statements are potentially defamatory.'}]

Once that state law determination is made, however, we must still look to federal bankruptcy law to resolve the extent to which that interest is property of the estate??under Â§ 541. Parks v. FIA Card Servs., N.A., 550 F.3d 1251, 1255 (10th Cir.2008) (citations and quotations omitted); 11 U.S.C. Â§ 541(a)(1). We first consider whether and to what extent Debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. Butner v. United States, 440 U.S. 48, 55, 99 S.Ct. 914, 59 L.Ed.2d 136 (1979); see, e.g., Williamson v. Hall, No. KS-08-088, 2009 WL 4456542, at *8 (10th Cir. BAP Dec. 4, 2009) (<HOLDING>). We then consider whether that interest [/INST]  As the court noted in Mathai v. Warren, 512 F.3d 1241, 1248 (10th Cir. 2008), for purposes of most bankruptcy proceedings, property interests are created and defined by state law. However, once that state law determination is made, federal bankruptcy law must be applied to resolve the extent to which that interest is property of the estate under 11 U.S.C. Â§ 541.

Therefore, in this case, the court must first consider whether and to what extent the debtors have an interest in the SARs under Kansas law. The court may then consider whether that interest is property of the estate under federal bankruptcy law.

It is worth noting that the court has held that an interest in a stock option is a property interest under Kansas law. See, e.g., In re Burrus, 336 B.R. 350, 357 (Bankr. D. Kan. 2005) (<HOLDING>). However, the court has also held that an interest in a stock option is not property of the estate under federal bankruptcy law. See, e.g., In re Fleming, 330 B.R. 736, 744 (Bankr. D. Kan. 2005) (<HOLDING>). Therefore, the court must carefully consider the relevant Kansas law and federal bankruptcy law in determining the extent to which the debtors' interest in the SARs is property of the estate."}]

column2: Bradley Nigh bought a car from Koons Buick Pontiac GMC. Nigh later sued action machine the dealership for intentionally charging him for a car feature for which he did not agree to pay. Nigh sued under the federal Truth in Lending Act (TILA). A federal district court awarded Nigh about $24,000. Koons Buick appealed and argued the district franchise court ignored TILA's cap on damages to $1,000. A Fourth Circuit held that a 1995 amendment to the act removed the nether $1,000 cap on recoveries involving loans secured by buy personal property.
